threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
This board is for the discussion of classic, or "retro" games, including consoles, computer games, arcade games (including pinball) and any other forms of video games. Retro gaming means platforms launched in 2001 and earlier, and official game titles for those platforms released no later than December 2007 (homebrew console games made after this date will be permitted). The Microsoft Xbox, Nintendo GameCube, Nintendo Game Boy Advance, and Sony PlayStation 2 will now be considered "retro".

Helpful links:
Game Tech Wiki
Emulation General Wiki

last_replies.com:
>>9464256
I've actually just started getting into GB/C bootlegs myself, so I'm still discovering stuff too. Truthfully I've spent more time collecting the ROMs than actually playing them so far. But as a Mega Man fan I really enjoy the "Zook" series. There are two on GBC (Zook Hero Z and Zook Hero 2) and one on GBA (Rockman & Crystal). Of course they aren't the level of quality you would expect from official Mega Man games, but they're very fascinating, but that's been my experience with just about every bootleg I've played on any system! There's also a similar game called Rockman 8 on GB, but I haven't tried that one yet. I'm really excited to try out all the various Digimon RPGs, like Digimon Crystal II, Digimon D-4, Digimon Sapphire, etc, as well as an original RPG (so I guess technically not a bootleg?) called Sheng Shou Wu Yu that taizou, the author of hhugboy, speaks highly of on his blog. That one hasn't been translated to my knowledge, so I'm gonna try to use google lens or something to play it. If you like platformers, there's Crash II Advance and Rayman IV, which are next on my list to try. If you haven't already, check out https://hhug.me, the blog of the author of hhugboy. He posts all of his dumps there and describes the games alongside screenshots, and shows what the carts and boxes look like and sometimes links to the manuals, if you're into that aspect of it.

>game as

>The themes the game dealt with couldn't clearly be understood at the time
The internet was still a crawling baby back then, there were no smartphones, people still used those tube TVs. Everyone still had telephones back then.

It's very easy to lose grasp of how the world worked back then, but keep that in mind. The theme deals with subjects like the consequences of widespread advanced technology, societal control, using technology for societal control. Obviously it's a coincidence, but it literally uses the fucking word MEME lmao

Keep in mind the game also deals with AI, and we aren't even there yet. So we are yet to fully be able to analyse the game in its entirety. Just as the game feels fresh nowadays, it will feel fresh again in 5, 10 or 15 years.

It's a very deep reflection about modern life, nobody can deny that

threads.filename: I have the cover off on purpose since it’s easier to troubleshoot that way

last_replies.name: Anonymous

ah well it was a junker ps2 anyways, I was also going to dot his anyways >>9464728 already had the SATA adaptee

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9464695
yeah first open it up and attempt basic maintenance. Clean the lens carefully (and dry it) as well as clean all 3 switches for the drive (front lid sensor, rear lid sensor, laser position sensor) and apply fresh WL grease to the rails after cleaning off the old.

If all fails, identify which laser module you have and look into a replacement, they're pretty affordable ($15 iirc?)

>Octogonal gate for analog sticks
>Nipple with small surface
>Unreliable D-Pad

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9462639
No rumble, and they have the PS2 style layout rather than the GameCube/Xbox/Switch Pro controller layout so if you're planning to do games that expect this layout then it might be rough. You do get two analog shoulders and two digital shoulder buttons (a ZL and ZR finally)

D Pad is pretty decent for what it is. I prefer this layout with the sticks out of the way for 2D platforming.

Analog sticks I believe use the same stick boxes as the nunchuck which use the same stick boxes as the last-revision GameCube controllers.

I don't like the ergonomics of the pad, lack of handles feels kinda weird but they designed it with a clip kinda thing where you could slot on a grip if you were so inclined.

Overall a 7/10 controller, coming from someone who thinks the GC controller is a 9/10 in a vacuum and 10/10 on games designed for it.

To be honest, I think most of the Expert Software releases were decent ports of the Saturn versions. Most of them are close to the Saturn versions with hardware accelerated enhancements. But some of the PC ports inherent some of the issues from the Saturn ports as well, like low framerates and mass pop-in. Most of these ports were never meant to be 'AAA' (so to speak) and were aimed to be sold at budget ware prices. Back in the day, getting Sega arcade ports based on their Saturn versions was still good enough, though, as you were getting lightly enhanced Saturn games for Windows 9x. I wish Sega could release them on GOG. But, I doubts that these ports will ever get official re-releases and may as well be counted as abandon ware. They are interesting versions to check out.

When installing a CR32 (or any kind of "watch" battery). NEVER HANDLE WITH BARE HANDS. The oils on your hands appear to decrease battery life drastically. Wear a surgical glove or handle with a cloth or tissue and you'll easily get 5 years of life from the battery.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9464061
Jurassic Park Arcade on Genesis would've run poorly like Super Thunder Blade and Space Harrier II. The Sega CD has proper scaling hardware that could handle a proper Super Scaler port. Panorama Cotton, though technically impressive, would've benefited greatly from the Sega CD hardware with scaling larger sprites (which are still somewhat choppy). Jurassic Park, which is mostly comprised of large, scaling sprites, would've been entirely different at best and completely awful at worst as a cartridge-based Genesis game. That said, Jurassic Park released in 1994, so it probably would've been a Sega Saturn game if it had a home release at all.

CRT-Guest-Advanced-NTSC. It's taken from guest's thread on the libretro forums. Apparently it's made to match a picture of a real NES hooked up to a PVM through composite, which explains the thick scanlines. The colors probably come down to the palette used. threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com: What are the best backwards compatible GBC games?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9463492
There is no objective way to tell. It's a philosophical question if anything. Is Pokemon Yellow a GBC game, when it's a direct conversion of the GB games Red/Blue/Green (and Japanese Yellow, which was not in color)? What about Gold and Silver, which were based on the same engine as Yellow and have the exact same system compatibility? What about Crystal, which does not even though it's nearly the same game?
There are games that essentially have a color version and a separate non-color version in the same ROM, with incompatible saves. What kind of compatible is that? Is it different in anything more than degree from a game that executes mostly the same code while periodically checking the platform?
>>9463525
File extension means nothing. I've seen full romsets give Pokemon Yellow .gb even though it's a color game, or Japanese Pokemon Yellow .gbc even though it's not.
If you want something more objective you can check the color flag in the ROM header. It will be <0x80 for GB, 0x80 for GB/GBC and 0xC0 for GBC only.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9463597
The question was which was their intent, but even that doesn't mean anything sometimes, as Donkey Kong Land games are very hard to play on actual GB but play much better on TV with SGB.
Yellow is same as RGB and Crystal is same as GS. Later on, adding something doesn't change the original idea behind the game, similarly to Link's Awakening DX.
Whether RGB is SGB or GB creation is a hard question given it has one of the best usages of SGB, but I still would go with GB because despite all the coloring SGB/GBC (Yellow) brings, it still looks like a monochrome game.
As for GSC it's very hard to tell. Most likely, the anser is "Yes". They tried to make it look good in both monochorme and GBC versions. How it started could still change the answer, I guess, but there is no correct answer for GSC.
But other GBC color games are going to be similar to Pokemon's coloring in that it was added later in development. Which is impossible to tell in some cases.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9463597
Crystal necessitated the extra space for the mobile GB adapter + I imagine gold and silver are maxxing out the capability and space of the original GB carts

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9463492
basically gameboy and gameboy color are the same thing from a software perspective. gameboy color exclusive games are just games that are too big to be played on the original, like trying to play a Windows 9X game on a DOS machine; it's the same shit really, but one computer isn't strong enough to play it; but the other computer can play both of them.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9463869
>Crystal necessitated the extra space for the mobile GB adapter
Mobile adapter used extra save space but that's a cartridge feature, not a Game Boy feature. Crystal was GBC-only because the expanded tilesets in Ecruteak/Olivine/Ice Path and Pokémon battle animations made use of the GBC's additional video RAM.

threads.com:
I really wanted to be a le contrarian on this one. I really did. I grew up on the first Earth Worm Jim on console and since have tried to play Earth Worm Jim 2 emulated, but for some reason could never find a copy that wouldn't freeze on level 2. That was decades ago. Finally I got my hands on a copy of the game and what the fuck...
>First level, classic Janky Earth Worm Jim platforming with zany humor. The level boss fake out was kind of funny, but I would have rather had something difficult like the trash creature in EWJ1.
>Level 2. Hot damn how did they pull this off on snes. It's fucking sick having a destructible environment where the excess dirt actually piles up for platforming use. It's not a totally fleshed out idea, but there were several times where I was rewarded by thinking "I wonder if I can reach up there..." The boss fight was the difficult sort of weirdness I remember well from the first game too.
>Third level. Yeah I expected a Peter Puppy level, but holy shit does this suck. The hit box on the marshmallow is god awful and took me 3 deaths to get used to. Also, 5 (or maybe 4) rounds? C'mon we didn't need more than 3.
>Level 4 is pretty much a swimming level, but you are a baby salamander floating through intestines. It's Fine, but after I did a stupid level can't I have a normal one? Interestingly enough this level gives you easy and hard paths. Why not just make the hard paths secrets or something? Also, no boss again, just a dumb simon says game that goes on for WAY too long.
>Level 5, I turned off the game at this point and decided to back to it later. What the hell is this? I don't even know what to compare it to. You are Jim on his space ship pushing a bomb across the level.
Does it get better? Do I have any normal levels to work towards? The first level had so many cool looking guns and I didn't even get to use them.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9457219
1. Start the specific game you want to play.
2. Pause and open Retroarch menu.
3. Scroll down to controls and adjust as needed. Hit save.
4. If you aren't sure - make sure you are in the "Quick Menu".

OR

Alternatively, you can adjust controls without starting a game by going to Settings > Input > Then scroll down and select which controller you want to adjust.
